Federated Few-shot Learning

Song Wang University of Virginia sw3wv@virginia.edu ,  Xingbo Fu University of Virginia xf3av@virginia.edu ,  Kaize Ding Arizona State University kaize.ding@asu.edu ,  Chen Chen University of Virginia zrh6du@virginia.edu ,  Huiyuan Chen Case Western Reserve University hxc501@case.edu  and  Jundong Li University of Virginia jundong@virginia.edu
(2023; 2023)
Abstract.

Federated Learning (FL) enables multiple clients to collaboratively learn a machine learning model without exchanging their own local data. In this way, the server can exploit the computational power of all clients and train the model on a larger set of data samples among all clients. Although such a mechanism is proven to be effective in various fields, existing works generally assume that each client preserves sufficient data for training. In practice, however, certain clients may only contain a limited number of samples (i.e., few-shot samples). For example, the available photo data taken by a specific user with a new mobile device is relatively rare. In this scenario, existing FL efforts typically encounter a significant performance drop on these clients. Therefore, it is urgent to develop a few-shot model that can generalize to clients with limited data under the FL scenario. In this paper, we refer to this novel problem as federated few-shot learning. Nevertheless, the problem remains challenging due to two major reasons: the global data variance among clients (i.e., the difference in data distributions among clients) and the local data insufficiency in each client (i.e., the lack of adequate local data for training). To overcome these two challenges, we propose a novel federated few-shot learning framework with two separately updated models and dedicated training strategies to reduce the adverse impact of global data variance and local data insufficiency. Extensive experiments on four prevalent datasets that cover news articles and images validate the effectiveness of our framework compared with the state-of-the-art baselines. Our code is provided111https://github.com/SongW-SW/F2L.

1. Introduction

The volume of valuable data is growing massively with the rapid development of mobile devices (Liu, 2011; Chakrabarti, 2002). Recently, researchers have developed various machine learning methods (Chau and Chen, 2008; Zhang and Segall, 2008; Xu et al., 2010) to analyze and extract useful information from such large-scale real-world data. Among these methods, Federated Learning (FL) is an effective solution, which aims to collaboratively optimize a centralized model over data distributed across a large number of clients (Collins et al., 2021; Zhao et al., 2018; Fallah et al., 2020; Kairouz et al., 2021). In particular, FL trains a global model on a server by aggregating the local models learned on each client (Briggs et al., 2020). Moreover, by avoiding the direct exchange of private data, FL can provide effective protection of local data privacy for clients (Li et al., 2021). As an example, in Google Photo Categorization (Duan et al., 2020; Lim et al., 2020), the server aims to learn an image classification model from photos distributed among a large number of clients, i.e., mobile devices. In this case, FL can effectively conduct learning tasks without revealing private photos to the server.

In fact, new learning tasks (e.g., novel photo classes) are constantly emerging over time (Tian et al., 2020; Yao et al., 2021). In consequence, FL can easily encounter a situation where the server needs to solve a new task with limited available data as the reference. In the previous example of Google Photo Categorization, as illustrated in Fig. 1, the server may inevitably need to deal with novel photo classes such as the latest electronic products, where only limited annotations are available. Nevertheless, existing FL works generally assume sufficient labeled samples for model training, which inevitably leads to unsatisfying classification performance for new tasks with limited labeled samples (Fan and Huang, 2021). Therefore, to improve the practicality of FL in realistic scenarios, it is important to solve this problem by learning an FL model that can achieve satisfactory performance on new tasks with limited samples. In this paper, we refer to this novel problem setting as federated few-shot learning.

Recently, many few-shot learning frameworks (Vinyals et al., 2016; Finn et al., 2017; Snell et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2022c) have been proposed to deal with new tasks with limited samples. Typically, the main idea is to learn meta-knowledge from base classes with abundant samples (e.g., photo classes such as portraits). Then such meta-knowledge is generalized to novel classes with limited samples (e.g., photo classes such as new electronic products), where novel classes are typically disjoint from base classes. However, as illustrated in Fig. 1, it remains challenging to conduct few-shot learning under the federated setting due to the following reasons. First, due to the global data variance (i.e., the differences in data distributions across clients), the aggregation of local models on the server side will disrupt the learning of meta-knowledge in each client (Karimireddy et al., 2020). Generally, the meta-knowledge is locally learned from different classes in each client and thus is distinct among clients, especially under the non-IID scenario, where the data variance can be even larger among clients compared with the IID scenario. Since the server will aggregate the local models from different clients and then send back the aggregated model, the learning of meta-knowledge in each client will be potentially disrupted. Second, due to the local data insufficiency in clients, it is non-trivial to learn meta-knowledge from each client. In FL, each client only preserves a relatively small portion of the total data (Arivazhagan et al., 2019; Fallah et al., 2020). However, meta-knowledge is generally learned from data in a variety of classes (Finn et al., 2017; Vinyals et al., 2016). As a result, it is difficult to learn meta-knowledge from data with less variety, especially in the non-IID scenario, where each client only has a limited amount of classes.

To effectively solve the aforementioned challenges, we propose a novel Federated Few-shot Learning framework, named F2L. First, we propose a decoupled meta-learning framework to mitigate the disruption from the aggregated model on the server. Specifically, the proposed framework retains a unique client-model for each client to learn meta-knowledge and a shared server-model to learn client-invariant knowledge (e.g., the representations of samples), as illustrated in Fig. 2. Specifically, the client-model in each client is updated locally and will not be shared across clients, while the server-model can be updated across clients and sent to the server for aggregation. Such a design decouples the learning of meta-knowledge (via client-model) from learning client-invariant knowledge (via server-model). In this way, we can mitigate the disruption from the aggregated model on the server caused by global data variance among clients. Second, to compensate for local data insufficiency in each client, we propose to leverage global knowledge learned from all clients with two dedicated update strategies. In particular, we first transfer the learned meta-knowledge in client-model to server-model by maximizing the mutual information between their output (i.e., local-to-global knowledge transfer). Then we propose a partial knowledge distillation strategy for each client to selectively extract useful knowledge from server-model (i.e., global-to-local knowledge distillation). In this manner, each client can leverage the beneficial knowledge in other clients to learn meta-knowledge from more data. In summary, our contributions are as follows:

  • •

    Problem. We investigate the challenges of learning meta-knowledge in the novel problem of federated few-shot learning from the perspectives of global data variance and local data insufficiency. We also discuss the necessity of tackling these challenges.

  • •

    Method. We develop a novel federated few-shot learning framework F2L with three essential strategies: (1) a decoupled meta-learning framework to mitigate disruption from the aggregated model on the server; (2) mutual information maximization for local-to-global knowledge transfer; (3) a novel partial knowledge distillation strategy for global-to-local knowledge distillation.

  • •

    Experiments. We conduct experiments on four few-shot classification datasets covering both news articles and images under the federated scenario. The results further demonstrate the superiority of our proposed framework.

2. Preliminaries

2.1. Problem Definition

In FL, given a set of I𝐼I clients, i.e., {ℂ(i)}i=1Isuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℂ𝑖𝑖1𝐼\{\mathbb{C}^{(i)}\}_{i=1}^{I}, where I𝐼I is the number of clients, each ℂ(i)superscriptℂ𝑖\mathbb{C}^{(i)} owns a local dataset 𝒟(i)superscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}^{(i)}. The main objective of FL is to learn a global model over data across all clients (i.e., {𝒟(i)}i=1Isuperscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑖1𝐼\{\mathcal{D}^{(i)}\}_{i=1}^{I}) without the direct exchange of data among clients. Following the conventional FL strategy (McMahan et al., 2017; Fallah et al., 2020; Li et al., 2020), a server 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S} will aggregate locally learned models from all clients for a global model.

Under the prevalent few-shot learning scenario, we consider a supervised setting in which the data samples for client ℂ(i)superscriptℂ𝑖\mathbb{C}^{(i)} are from its local dataset: (x,y)∈𝒟(i)𝑥𝑦superscript𝒟𝑖(x,y)\in\mathcal{D}^{(i)}, where x𝑥x is a data sample, and y𝑦y is the corresponding label. We first denote the entire set of classes on all clients as 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C}. Depending on the number of labeled samples in each class, 𝒞𝒞\mathcal{C} can be divided into two categories: base classes 𝒞bsubscript𝒞𝑏\mathcal{C}_{b} and novel classes 𝒞nsubscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{C}_{n}, where 𝒞=𝒞b∪𝒞n𝒞subscript𝒞𝑏subscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{C}=\mathcal{C}_{b}\cup\mathcal{C}_{n} and 𝒞b∩𝒞n=∅subscript𝒞𝑏subscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{C}_{b}\cap\mathcal{C}_{n}=\emptyset. In general, the number of labeled samples in 𝒞bsubscript𝒞𝑏\mathcal{C}_{b} is sufficient, while it is generally small in 𝒞nsubscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{C}_{n} (Finn et al., 2017; Snell et al., 2017). Correspondingly, each local dataset can be divided into a base dataset 𝒟b(i)={(x,y)∈𝒟(i):y∈𝒞b}subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑏conditional-set𝑥𝑦superscript𝒟𝑖𝑦subscript𝒞𝑏\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{b}=\{(x,y)\in\mathcal{D}^{(i)}:y\in\mathcal{C}_{b}\} and a novel dataset 𝒟n(i)={(x,y)∈𝒟(i):y∈𝒞n}subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑛conditional-set𝑥𝑦superscript𝒟𝑖𝑦subscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{n}=\{(x,y)\in\mathcal{D}^{(i)}:y\in\mathcal{C}_{n}\}. In the few-shot setting, the evaluation of the model generalizability to novel classes 𝒞nsubscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{C}_{n} is conducted on 𝒟n(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑛\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{n}, which contains only limited labeled samples. The data samples in 𝒟b(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑏\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{b} will be used for training. Then we can formulate the studied problem of federated few-shot learning as follows:

Definition 0.

Federated Few-shot Learning: Given a set of III clients {ℂ(i)}i=1Isuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℂii1I\{\mathbb{C}^{(i)}\}_{i=1}^{I} and a server 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S}, federated few-shot learning aims to learn a global model after aggregating model parameters locally learned from 𝒟b(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟ib\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{b} in each client such that the model can accurately predict labels for unlabeled samples (i.e., query set 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}) in 𝒟n(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟in\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{n} with only a limited number of labeled samples (i.e., support set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}).

More specifically, if the support set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} consists of exactly K𝐾K labeled samples for each of N𝑁N classes from 𝒟n(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑛\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{n}, and the query set 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} is sampled from the same N𝑁N classes, the problem is defined as Federated N𝑁N-way K𝐾K-shot Learning. Essentially, the objective of federated few-shot learning is to learn a globally shared model across clients that can be fast adapted to data samples in 𝒟n(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑛\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{n} with only limited labeled samples. Therefore, the crucial part is to effectively learn meta-knowledge from the base datasets {𝒟b(i)}i=1Isuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑏𝑖𝑖1𝐼\{\mathcal{D}_{b}^{(i)}\}_{i=1}^{I} in all clients. Such meta-knowledge is generalizable to novel classes unseen during training and thus can be utilized to classify data samples in each 𝒟n(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑛\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{n}, which consists of only limited labeled samples.

2.2. Episodic Learning

In practice, we adopt the prevalent episodic learning framework for model training and evaluation, which has proven to be effective in various few-shot learning scenarios (Vinyals et al., 2016; Oreshkin et al., 2018; Ding et al., 2020; Wang et al., 2021; Ding et al., 2021). Specifically, the model evaluation (i.e., meta-test) is conducted on a certain number of meta-test tasks, where each task contains a small number of labeled samples as references and unlabeled samples for classification. The local model training (i.e., meta-training) process in each client is similarly conducted on a specific number of meta-training tasks, where each task mimics the structure of meta-test tasks. It is worth mentioning that meta-training tasks are sampled from the local base dataset 𝒟b(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑏\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{b} of each client, while meta-test tasks are sampled from the local novel dataset 𝒟n(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑛\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{n}. That being said, the class set of samples in meta-training tasks is a subset of 𝒞bsubscript𝒞𝑏\mathcal{C}_{b}, while the class set of samples in meta-test tasks is a subset of 𝒞nsubscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{C}_{n}, which is distinct from 𝒞bsubscript𝒞𝑏\mathcal{C}_{b}. The main idea of federated few-shot learning is to preserve the consistency between meta-training and meta-test so that the model can learn meta-knowledge from clients for better generalization performance to novel classes 𝒞nsubscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{C}_{n}.

Specifically, to construct a meta-training task 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} in client ℂ(i)superscriptℂ𝑖\mathbb{C}^{(i)} from its local base dataset 𝒟b(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑏\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{b}, we first randomly sample N𝑁N classes from 𝒟b(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑏\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{b}. Then we randomly select K𝐾K samples from each of the N𝑁N classes (i.e., N𝑁N-way K𝐾K-shot) to establish the support set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}. Similarly, the query set 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} consists of Q𝑄Q different samples (distinct from 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}) from the same N𝑁N classes. The components of the meta-training task 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T} is formulated as follows:

(1) 𝒮𝒮\displaystyle\mathcal{S} ={(x1,y1),(x2,y2),…,(xN×K,yN×K)},absentsubscript𝑥1subscript𝑦1subscript𝑥2subscript𝑦2…subscript𝑥𝑁𝐾subscript𝑦𝑁𝐾\displaystyle=\{(x_{1},y_{1}),(x_{2},y_{2}),\dotsc,(x_{N\times K},y_{N\times K})\},
𝒬𝒬\displaystyle\mathcal{Q} ={(q1,y1′),(q2,y2′),…,(qQ,yQ′)},absentsubscript𝑞1subscriptsuperscript𝑦′1subscript𝑞2subscriptsuperscript𝑦′2…subscript𝑞𝑄subscriptsuperscript𝑦′𝑄\displaystyle=\{(q_{1},y^{\prime}_{1}),(q_{2},y^{\prime}_{2}),\dotsc,(q_{Q},y^{\prime}_{Q})\},
𝒯𝒯\displaystyle\mathcal{T} ={𝒮,𝒬},absent𝒮𝒬\displaystyle=\{\mathcal{S},\mathcal{Q}\},

where xisubscript𝑥𝑖x_{i} (or qi)q_{i}) is a data sample in the sampled N𝑁N classes, and yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} (or yi′subscriptsuperscript𝑦′𝑖y^{\prime}_{i}) is the corresponding label. Note that during meta-test, each meta-test task shares a similar structure to meta-training tasks, except that the samples are from the local novel dataset 𝒟n(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑛\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{n}, which are distinct from 𝒟b(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑏\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{b}.

3. Methodology

In this part, we introduce the overall design of our proposed framework F2L in detail. Specifically, we formulate the federated few-shot learning problem under the prevailing N𝑁N-way K𝐾K-shot learning framework. Our target of conducting federated few-shot learning is to learn meta-knowledge from a set of I𝐼I clients {ℂ(i)}i=1Isuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptℂ𝑖𝑖1𝐼\{\mathbb{C}^{(i)}\}_{i=1}^{I} with different data distributions, and generalize such meta-knowledge to meta-test tasks. Nevertheless, it remains difficult to conduct federated few-shot learning due to the challenging issues of global data variance and local data insufficiency as mentioned before. Therefore, as illustrated in Fig 2, we propose a decoupled meta-learning framework to mitigate disruption from the servers. We further propose two update strategies to leverage global knowledge. The overview process is presented in Fig 3.

3.1. Decoupled Meta-Learning Framework

3.1.1. Federated Learning Framework

We consider a server-model, which consists of an encoder qϕsubscript𝑞italic-ϕq_{\phi} and a classifier fϕsubscript𝑓italic-ϕf_{\phi} that are shared among clients. We denote the overall model parameters in the server-model as ϕitalic-ϕ\phi. Specifically, qϕ:ℝd→ℝk:subscript𝑞italic-ϕ→superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptℝ𝑘q_{\phi}:\mathbb{R}^{d}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}^{k} is a function that maps each sample into a low-dimensional vector 𝐡ϕ∈ℝksubscript𝐡italic-ϕsuperscriptℝ𝑘\mathbf{h}_{\phi}\in\mathbb{R}^{k}, where d𝑑d is the input feature dimension, and k𝑘k is the dimension of learned representations. Taking the representation 𝐡ϕsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ\mathbf{h}_{\phi} as input, the classifier fϕ:ℝk→𝒞b:subscript𝑓italic-ϕ→superscriptℝ𝑘subscript𝒞𝑏f_{\phi}:\mathbb{R}^{k}\rightarrow\mathcal{C}_{b} maps each 𝐡ϕsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ\mathbf{h}_{\phi} to the label space of base classes 𝒞bsubscript𝒞𝑏\mathcal{C}_{b} and outputs the prediction 𝐩ϕ∈ℝ|𝒞b|subscript𝐩italic-ϕsuperscriptℝsubscript𝒞𝑏\mathbf{p}_{\phi}\in\mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{C}_{b}|}, where each element in 𝐩ϕsubscript𝐩italic-ϕ\mathbf{p}_{\phi} denotes the classification probability regarding each class in 𝒞bsubscript𝒞𝑏\mathcal{C}_{b}.

Following the prevalent FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017) strategy for FL, the training of server-model is conducted on all clients through T𝑇T rounds. In each round t𝑡t, the server 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S} first sends the server-model parameters ϕitalic-ϕ\phi to all clients, and each client will conduct a local meta-training process on τ𝜏\tau randomly sampled meta-training tasks. Then the server 𝕊𝕊\mathbb{S} will perform aggregation on parameters received from clients:

(2) ϕt+1=1I​∑i=1Iϕ~it,superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡11𝐼superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐼superscriptsubscript~italic-ϕ𝑖𝑡\phi^{t+1}=\frac{1}{I}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{I}\widetilde{\phi}_{i}^{t},

where ϕ~itsuperscriptsubscript~italic-ϕ𝑖𝑡\widetilde{\phi}_{i}^{t} denotes the locally updated server-model parameters by client ℂ(i)superscriptℂ𝑖\mathbb{C}^{(i)} on round t𝑡t. ϕt+1superscriptitalic-ϕ𝑡1\phi^{t+1} denotes the aggregated server-model parameters which will be distributed to clients at the beginning of the next round. In this way, the server can learn a shared model for all clients in a federated manner.

Although the standard strategy of learning a single shared model for all clients achieves decent performance on general FL tasks (McMahan et al., 2017; Fallah et al., 2020), it can be suboptimal for federated few-shot learning. Due to the global data variance among clients, the aggregated model on the server will disrupt the learning of meta-knowledge in each client (Karimireddy et al., 2020). As a result, the local learning of meta-knowledge in clients will become more difficult. In contrast, we propose to further introduce a client-model, which is uniquely learned and preserved by each client, to locally learn meta-knowledge. In other words, its model parameters will not be sent back to the server for aggregation. In this manner, we can separate the learning of client-model (meta-knowledge) and server-model (client-invariant knowledge) so that the learning of meta-knowledge is not disrupted.

Specifically, for client ℂ(i)superscriptℂ𝑖\mathbb{C}^{(i)}, the client-model also consists of an encoder qψisubscript𝑞subscript𝜓𝑖q_{\psi_{i}} and a classifier fψisubscript𝑓subscript𝜓𝑖f_{\psi_{i}}. We denote the overall model parameters in the client-model for client ℂ(i)superscriptℂ𝑖\mathbb{C}^{(i)} as ψisubscript𝜓𝑖\psi_{i}. In particular, the encoder qψisubscript𝑞subscript𝜓𝑖q_{\psi_{i}} takes the representation 𝐡ϕsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ\mathbf{h}_{\phi} learned by the encoder qϕsubscript𝑞italic-ϕq_{\phi} in server-model as input, and outputs a hidden representation 𝐡ψ∈ℝksubscript𝐡𝜓superscriptℝ𝑘\mathbf{h}_{\psi}\in\mathbb{R}^{k}. Such a design ensures that the client-model encoder qψisubscript𝑞subscript𝜓𝑖q_{\psi_{i}} does not need to process the raw sample and thus can be a small model, which is important when clients only preserve limited computational resources (Chen et al., 2018). Then the classifier fψisubscript𝑓subscript𝜓𝑖f_{\psi_{i}} maps 𝐡ψsubscript𝐡𝜓\mathbf{h}_{\psi} to predictions 𝐩ψ∈ℝNsubscript𝐩𝜓superscriptℝ𝑁\mathbf{p}_{\psi}\in\mathbb{R}^{N} of the N𝑁N classes.

3.1.2. Local Meta-training on Clients

Based on the episodic learning strategy, in each round, the training process of each client ℂ(i)superscriptℂ𝑖\mathbb{C}^{(i)} is conducted through τ𝜏\tau steps, where each step is a local update based on a meta-training task randomly sampled from the local base dataset 𝒟b(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑏\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{b}. In particular, for client ℂ(i)superscriptℂ𝑖\mathbb{C}^{(i)} on round t=1,2,…,T𝑡12…𝑇t=1,2,\dotsc,T and step s=1,2,…,τ𝑠12…𝜏s=1,2,\dotsc,\tau, we denote the sampled meta-task as 𝒯it,s={𝒮it,s,𝒬it,s}superscriptsubscript𝒯𝑖𝑡𝑠superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑖𝑡𝑠superscriptsubscript𝒬𝑖𝑡𝑠\mathcal{T}_{i}^{t,s}=\{\mathcal{S}_{i}^{t,s},\mathcal{Q}_{i}^{t,s}\}. To learn meta-knowledge from meta-task 𝒯it,ssuperscriptsubscript𝒯𝑖𝑡𝑠\mathcal{T}_{i}^{t,s}, we adopt the prevalent MAML (Finn et al., 2017) strategy to update client-model in one fine-tuning step and one meta-update step. We first fine-tune the client-model to fast adapt it to support set 𝒮it,ssuperscriptsubscript𝒮𝑖𝑡𝑠\mathcal{S}_{i}^{t,s}:

(3) ψ~it,s=ψit,s−αf​t​∇ψℒf​t​(𝒮it,s;{ϕit,s,ψit,s}),superscriptsubscript~𝜓𝑖𝑡𝑠superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖𝑡𝑠subscript𝛼𝑓𝑡subscript∇𝜓subscriptℒ𝑓𝑡superscriptsubscript𝒮𝑖𝑡𝑠superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑡𝑠superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖𝑡𝑠\widetilde{\psi}_{i}^{t,s}=\psi_{i}^{t,s}-\alpha_{ft}\nabla_{\psi}\mathcal{L}_{ft}\left(\mathcal{S}_{i}^{t,s};\{\phi_{i}^{t,s},\psi_{i}^{t,s}\}\right),

where ℒf​tsubscriptℒ𝑓𝑡\mathcal{L}_{ft} is the fine-tuning loss, which is the cross-entropy loss calculated on the support set 𝒮it,ssuperscriptsubscript𝒮𝑖𝑡𝑠\mathcal{S}_{i}^{t,s}. Here, αf​tsubscript𝛼𝑓𝑡\alpha_{ft} is the learning rate, and ψit,ssuperscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖𝑡𝑠\psi_{i}^{t,s} (or ϕit,ssuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑡𝑠\phi_{i}^{t,s}) denotes the parameters of client-model (or server-model) on round t𝑡t and step s𝑠s. Then we update the client-model based on the query set 𝒬it,ssuperscriptsubscript𝒬𝑖𝑡𝑠\mathcal{Q}_{i}^{t,s}:

(4) ψit,s+1=ψit,s−αψ​∇ψℒψ​(𝒬it,s;{ϕit,s,ψ~it,s}),superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖𝑡𝑠1superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖𝑡𝑠subscript𝛼𝜓subscript∇𝜓subscriptℒ𝜓superscriptsubscript𝒬𝑖𝑡𝑠superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑡𝑠superscriptsubscript~𝜓𝑖𝑡𝑠\psi_{i}^{t,s+1}=\psi_{i}^{t,s}-\alpha_{\psi}\nabla_{\psi}\mathcal{L}_{\psi}\left(\mathcal{Q}_{i}^{t,s};\{\phi_{i}^{t,s},\widetilde{\psi}_{i}^{t,s}\}\right),

where ℒψsubscriptℒ𝜓\mathcal{L}_{\psi} is the loss for client-model on the query set 𝒬it,ssuperscriptsubscript𝒬𝑖𝑡𝑠\mathcal{Q}_{i}^{t,s}, and αψsubscript𝛼𝜓\alpha_{\psi} is the meta-learning rate for ψ𝜓\psi. In this regard, we can update client-model with our global-to-local knowledge distillation strategy. For the update of server-model, we conduct one step of update based on the support set and parameters of client-model:

(5) ϕit,s+1=ϕit,s−αϕ​∇ϕℒϕ​(𝒮it,s;{ϕit,s,ψit,s}),superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑡𝑠1superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑡𝑠subscript𝛼italic-ϕsubscript∇italic-ϕsubscriptℒitalic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝒮𝑖𝑡𝑠superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑡𝑠superscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖𝑡𝑠\phi_{i}^{t,s+1}=\phi_{i}^{t,s}-\alpha_{\phi}\nabla_{\phi}\mathcal{L}_{\phi}\left(\mathcal{S}_{i}^{t,s};\{\phi_{i}^{t,s},\psi_{i}^{t,s}\}\right),

where ℒϕsubscriptℒitalic-ϕ\mathcal{L}_{\phi} is the loss for the server-model, and αϕsubscript𝛼italic-ϕ\alpha_{\phi} is the meta-learning rate for ϕitalic-ϕ\phi. In this manner, we can update the server-model with our local-to-global knowledge transfer strategy. After repeating the above updates for τ𝜏\tau steps, the final parameters of server-model ϕit,τsuperscriptsubscriptitalic-ϕ𝑖𝑡𝜏\phi_{i}^{t,\tau} is used as ϕ~itsuperscriptsubscript~italic-ϕ𝑖𝑡\widetilde{\phi}_{i}^{t} in Eq. (2) and sent back to the server for aggregation, while the client-model (with parameters ψit,τsuperscriptsubscript𝜓𝑖𝑡𝜏\psi_{i}^{t,\tau}) will be kept locally. By doing this, we can decouple the learning of local meta-knowledge in client-model while learning client-invariant knowledge in server-model to avoid disruption from the server.

3.2. Local-to-Global Knowledge Transfer

With our decoupled meta-learning framework, we can mitigate the disruption to the learning of local meta-knowledge in each client. Nevertheless, we still need to transfer the learned meta-knowledge to server-model (i.e., Local-to-global Knowledge Transfer), so that it can be further leveraged by other clients to handle the local data insufficiency issue. Specifically, to effectively transfer local meta-knowledge, we propose to maximize the mutual information between representations learned from server-model encoder qϕsubscript𝑞italic-ϕq_{\phi} and client-model encoder qψsubscript𝑞𝜓q_{\psi}. In this way, the server-model can maximally absorb the information in the learned local meta-knowledge.

3.2.1. Mutual Information Maximization

Given a meta-training task 𝒯={𝒮,𝒬}𝒯𝒮𝒬\mathcal{T}=\{\mathcal{S},\mathcal{Q}\}, as described in Sec. 3.1, the server-model encoder qϕsubscript𝑞italic-ϕq_{\phi} and client-model encoder qψsubscript𝑞𝜓q_{\psi} will output 𝐡ϕsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ\mathbf{h}_{\phi} and 𝐡ψsubscript𝐡𝜓\mathbf{h}_{\psi} for each sample, respectively. By stacking the learned representations of samples in the support set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} (|𝒮|=D𝒮𝐷|\mathcal{S}|=D, where D=N×K𝐷𝑁𝐾D=N\times K), we can obtain the representations of support samples learned by the server-model, i.e., 𝐇ϕ∈ℝD×ksubscript𝐇italic-ϕsuperscriptℝ𝐷𝑘\mathbf{H}_{\phi}\in\mathbb{R}^{D\times k}, and the client-model, i.e., 𝐇ψ∈ℝD×ksubscript𝐇𝜓superscriptℝ𝐷𝑘\mathbf{H}_{\psi}\in\mathbb{R}^{D\times k}. For simplicity, we omit the annotations of round t𝑡t, step s𝑠s, and client i𝑖i. The objective of maximizing the information between 𝐇ϕsubscript𝐇italic-ϕ\mathbf{H}_{\phi} and 𝐇ψsubscript𝐇𝜓\mathbf{H}_{\psi} can be formally represented as follows:

(6) maxϕ⁡I​(𝐇ϕ;𝐇ψ)=maxϕ​∑i=1D∑j=1Dp​(𝐡ϕi,𝐡ψj;ϕ)​log⁡p​(𝐡ψj|𝐡ϕi;ϕ)p​(𝐡ϕj;ϕ),subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐼subscript𝐇italic-ϕsubscript𝐇𝜓subscriptitalic-ϕsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐷𝑝superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕ𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖italic-ϕ𝑝superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑗italic-ϕ\max_{\phi}I(\mathbf{H}_{\phi};\mathbf{H}_{\psi})=\max_{\phi}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{D}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{D}p(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i},\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi)\log\frac{p(\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}|\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i};\phi)}{p(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{j};\phi)},

where 𝐡ϕisuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i} (or 𝐡ψisuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑖\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{i}) is the i𝑖i-th row of 𝐇ϕsubscript𝐇italic-ϕ\mathbf{H}_{\phi} (or 𝐇ψsubscript𝐇𝜓\mathbf{H}_{\psi}). Since the mutual information I​(𝐇ϕ;𝐇ψ)𝐼subscript𝐇italic-ϕsubscript𝐇𝜓I(\mathbf{H}_{\phi};\mathbf{H}_{\psi}) is difficult to obtain and thus infeasible to be maximized (Oord et al., 2018), we re-write it to achieve a more feasible form:

(7) I​(𝐇ϕ;𝐇ψ)𝐼subscript𝐇italic-ϕsubscript𝐇𝜓\displaystyle I(\mathbf{H}_{\phi};\mathbf{H}_{\psi}) =∑i=1D∑j=1Dp​(𝐡ϕi|𝐡ψj;ϕ)​p​(𝐡ψj;ϕ)​log⁡p​(𝐡ψj|𝐡ϕi;ϕ)p​(𝐡ψj;ϕ).absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐷𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕ𝑝superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕ𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖italic-ϕ𝑝superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕ\displaystyle=\sum\limits_{i=1}^{D}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{D}p(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}|\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi)p(\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi)\log\frac{p(\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}|\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i};\phi)}{p(\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi)}.

Since the support set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} of size D𝐷D is randomly sampled, we can assume that the prior probability p​(𝐡ψj;ϕ)𝑝superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕp(\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi) follows a uniform distribution, and set it as p​(𝐡ψj;ϕ)=1/D𝑝superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕ1𝐷p(\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi)=1/D. According to the Bayes’ theorem, the Eq. (7) becomes:

(8) I​(𝐇ϕ;𝐇ψ)𝐼subscript𝐇italic-ϕsubscript𝐇𝜓\displaystyle I(\mathbf{H}_{\phi};\mathbf{H}_{\psi}) =1D​∑i=1D∑j=1Dp​(𝐡ϕi|𝐡ψj;ϕ)​(log⁡(p​(𝐡ψj|𝐡ϕi;ϕ))+log⁡D).absent1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐷𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕ𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖italic-ϕ𝐷\displaystyle=\frac{1}{D}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{D}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{D}p(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}|\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi)\left(\log(p(\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}|\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i};\phi))+\log D\right).

We next present alternative strategies to estimate p​(𝐡ϕi|𝐡ψj;ϕ)𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕp(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}|\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi) and p​(𝐡ψj|𝐡ϕi;ϕ)𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖italic-ϕp(\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}|\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i};\phi) in detail.

3.2.2. Estimation of p​(𝐡ϕi|𝐡ψj;ϕ)𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕp(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}|\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi)

Since the client-model is fine-tuned on the support set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} of the meta-task 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}, we can leverage the classification results of the client-model to estimate p​(𝐡ϕi|𝐡ψj;ϕ)𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕp(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}|\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi). We denote C​(j)𝐶𝑗C(j) as the set of sample indices in the support set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} that shares the same class as the j𝑗j-th sample (including itself), i.e., C​(j)≡{k:yk=yj,k=1,2,…,D}𝐶𝑗conditional-set𝑘formulae-sequencesubscript𝑦𝑘subscript𝑦𝑗𝑘12…𝐷C(j)\equiv\{k:y_{k}=y_{j},k=1,2,\dotsc,D\}. Here, we first set p​(𝐡ϕi|𝐡ψj;ϕ)=0𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕ0p(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}|\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi)=0 for all i∉C​(j)𝑖𝐶𝑗i\notin C(j), since we assume the client-model can only infer representations from the same class. Intuitively, in the case of i∈C​(j)𝑖𝐶𝑗i\in C(j), which means the i𝑖i-th and the j𝑗j-th samples share the same class, p​(𝐡ϕi|𝐡ψj;ϕ)𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕp(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}|\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi) can be considered as the confidence of client-model regarding the class of the j𝑗j-the sample. Therefore, it should reflect the degree to which the sample representation 𝐡ψjsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j} is relevant to its class. Utilizing the client-model classification output (i.e., normalized class probabilities) for the i𝑖i-th sample 𝐩ψi∈ℝNsubscriptsuperscript𝐩𝑖𝜓superscriptℝ𝑁\mathbf{p}^{i}_{\psi}\in\mathbb{R}^{N}, we can compute p​(𝐡ϕi|𝐡ψj;ϕ)𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕp(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}|\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi) as follows:

(9) p(𝐡ϕi|𝐡ψj;ϕ)={𝐩ψi​(yj)∑k∈C​(j)𝐩ψk​(yj)ifi∈C​(j)0otherwise,p(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}|\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi)=\left\{\begin{aligned} \frac{\mathbf{p}^{i}_{\psi}(y_{j})}{\sum_{k\in C(j)}\mathbf{p}^{k}_{\psi}(y_{j})}&\ \ \ \ \ \ \text{if}\ \ i\in C(j)\\ 0\ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ \ &\ \ \ \ \ \ \text{otherwise}\end{aligned}\right.,

where 𝐩ψi​(yj)∈ℝsuperscriptsubscript𝐩𝜓𝑖subscript𝑦𝑗ℝ\mathbf{p}_{\psi}^{i}(y_{j})\in\mathbb{R} denotes the classification probability for the i𝑖i-th sample regarding class yjsubscript𝑦𝑗y_{j} (yi=yjsubscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑦𝑗y_{i}=y_{j} when i∈C​(j)𝑖𝐶𝑗i\in C(j)).

3.2.3. Estimation of p​(𝐡ψj|𝐡ϕi;ϕ)𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖italic-ϕp(\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}|\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i};\phi)

Next we elaborate on how to estimate p​(𝐡ψj|𝐡ϕi;ϕ)𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖italic-ϕp(\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}|\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i};\phi). Although we can similarly leverage the classification results of the server-model, such a strategy lacks generalizability. This is because the server-model aims at classifying all base classes instead of the N𝑁N classes in each meta-training task. We instead propose to estimate p​(𝐡ψj|𝐡ϕi;ϕ)𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖italic-ϕp(\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}|\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i};\phi) based on the Euclidean distance (divided by 2 for simplicity) between learned representations of the server-model and the client-model. Specifically, we normalize the distances with a softmax function:

(10) p​(𝐡ψj|𝐡ϕi;ϕ)=exp⁡(−‖𝐡ϕi−𝐡ψj‖22/2)∑k∈C​(i)exp⁡(−‖𝐡ϕi−𝐡ψk‖22/2).𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖italic-ϕsuperscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗222subscript𝑘𝐶𝑖superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑘222\left.p(\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}|\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i};\phi)=\frac{\exp\left(-\|\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}-\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}\|_{2}^{2}/2\right)}{\sum_{k\in C(i)}\exp\left(-\|\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}-\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{k}\|_{2}^{2}/2\right)}\right..

Then if we further apply the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2} normalization to both 𝐡ϕisuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i} and 𝐡ψjsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}, we can obtain ‖𝐡ϕi−𝐡ψj‖22/2=1−𝐡ϕi⋅𝐡ψjsuperscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗2221⋅superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗\|\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}-\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}\|_{2}^{2}/2=1-\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}\cdot\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}. Moreover, since the value of ∑i=1D∑j=1Dp​(𝐡ϕi|𝐡ψj;ϕ)superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐷𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕ\sum_{i=1}^{D}\sum_{j=1}^{D}p(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}|\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi) equals a constant D𝐷D, the term ∑i=1D∑j=1Dp​(𝐡ϕi|𝐡ψj;ϕ)⋅log⁡(D)/Dsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐷⋅𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕ𝐷𝐷\sum_{i=1}^{D}\sum_{j=1}^{D}p(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}|\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi)\cdot\log(D)/D in Eq. (8) is also a constant and thus can be ignored in the objective:

(11) 1D​∑i=1D∑j=1Dp​(𝐡ϕi|𝐡ψj;ϕ)​log⁡(D)=1D⋅D⋅log⁡(D)=log⁡(D).1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐷𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕ𝐷⋅1𝐷𝐷𝐷𝐷\frac{1}{D}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{D}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{D}p(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}|\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi)\log\left(D\right)=\frac{1}{D}\cdot D\cdot\log\left(D\right)=\log\left(D\right).

Combining the above equations, the optimal server-model parameter ϕ∗superscriptitalic-ϕ\phi^{*} for the final optimization objective (i.e., maxϕ⁡I​(𝐇ϕ;𝐇ψ)subscriptitalic-ϕ𝐼subscript𝐇italic-ϕsubscript𝐇𝜓\max_{\phi}I(\mathbf{H}_{\phi};\mathbf{H}_{\psi})) can be obtained as follows:

(12) ϕ∗=argmaxϕI​(𝐇ϕ;𝐇ψ)=argminϕℒM​I.superscriptitalic-ϕsubscriptargmaxitalic-ϕ𝐼subscript𝐇italic-ϕsubscript𝐇𝜓subscriptargminitalic-ϕsubscriptℒ𝑀𝐼\phi^{*}=\operatorname*{argmax}_{\phi}I(\mathbf{H}_{\phi};\mathbf{H}_{\psi})=\operatorname*{argmin}_{\phi}\mathcal{L}_{MI}.

Here ℒM​Isubscriptℒ𝑀𝐼\mathcal{L}_{MI} is defined as follows:

(13) ℒM​Isubscriptℒ𝑀𝐼\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{MI} =1D​∑i=1D∑j=1Dp​(𝐡ϕi|𝐡ψj;ϕ)​log⁡(p​(𝐡ψj|𝐡ϕi;ϕ))absent1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐷𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗italic-ϕ𝑝conditionalsuperscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖italic-ϕ\displaystyle=\frac{1}{D}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{D}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{D}p(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}|\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j};\phi)\log(p(\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}|\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i};\phi))
=1D​∑j=1D∑i∈C​(j)−𝐩ψi​(yj)​(𝐡ϕi⋅𝐡ψj)∑k∈C​(j)𝐩ψk​(yj)absent1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐷subscript𝑖𝐶𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐩𝑖𝜓subscript𝑦𝑗⋅superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑗subscript𝑘𝐶𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐩𝑘𝜓subscript𝑦𝑗\displaystyle=\frac{1}{D}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{D}\sum\limits_{i\in C(j)}-\frac{\mathbf{p}^{i}_{\psi}(y_{j})\left(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}\cdot\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{j}\right)}{\sum_{k\in C(j)}\mathbf{p}^{k}_{\psi}(y_{j})}
+𝐩ψi​(yj)∑k∈C​(j)𝐩ψk​(yj)​log⁡(∑k∈C​(i)exp⁡(𝐡ϕi⋅𝐡ψk)),subscriptsuperscript𝐩𝑖𝜓subscript𝑦𝑗subscript𝑘𝐶𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐩𝑘𝜓subscript𝑦𝑗subscript𝑘𝐶𝑖⋅superscriptsubscript𝐡italic-ϕ𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐡𝜓𝑘\displaystyle+\frac{\mathbf{p}^{i}_{\psi}(y_{j})}{\sum_{k\in C(j)}\mathbf{p}^{k}_{\psi}(y_{j})}\log\left(\sum_{k\in C(i)}\exp\left(\mathbf{h}_{\phi}^{i}\cdot\mathbf{h}_{\psi}^{k}\right)\right),

where we exchange the order of summation over i𝑖i and j𝑗j for clarity. It is noteworthy that ℒM​Isubscriptℒ𝑀𝐼\mathcal{L}_{MI} is different from the InfoNCE loss (Oord et al., 2018; He et al., 2020), which considers different augmentations of samples, while ℒM​Isubscriptℒ𝑀𝐼\mathcal{L}_{MI} focuses on the classes of samples in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S}. Moreover, ℒM​Isubscriptℒ𝑀𝐼\mathcal{L}_{MI} also differs from the supervised contrastive loss (Khosla et al., 2020), which combines various augmentations of samples and label information. In contrast, our loss targets at transferring the meta-knowledge by maximally preserving the mutual information between representations learned by the server-model and the client-model. More differently, the term 𝐩ψi​(yj)/∑k∈C​(j)𝐩ψk​(yj)subscriptsuperscript𝐩𝑖𝜓subscript𝑦𝑗subscript𝑘𝐶𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐩𝑘𝜓subscript𝑦𝑗\mathbf{p}^{i}_{\psi}(y_{j})/\sum_{k\in C(j)}\mathbf{p}^{k}_{\psi}(y_{j}) acts as an adjustable weight that measures the importance of a sample to its class. Combining the objective described in Eq. (13) and the standard cross-entropy loss, we can obtain the final loss for the server-model:

(14) ℒϕsubscriptℒitalic-ϕ\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{\phi} =(1−λM​I)​ℒC​E​(𝒮)+λM​I​ℒM​I,absent1subscript𝜆𝑀𝐼subscriptℒ𝐶𝐸𝒮subscript𝜆𝑀𝐼subscriptℒ𝑀𝐼\displaystyle=(1-\lambda_{MI})\mathcal{L}_{CE}(\mathcal{S})+\lambda_{MI}\mathcal{L}_{MI},

where ℒC​E​(𝒮)subscriptℒ𝐶𝐸𝒮\mathcal{L}_{CE}(\mathcal{S}) is defined as follows:

(15) ℒC​E​(𝒮)subscriptℒ𝐶𝐸𝒮\displaystyle\mathcal{L}_{CE}(\mathcal{S}) =−1D​∑i=1D∑j=1|𝒞b|ycji​log⁡𝐩ϕi​(cj),absent1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑗1subscript𝒞𝑏subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐩𝑖italic-ϕsubscript𝑐𝑗\displaystyle=-\frac{1}{D}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{D}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{|\mathcal{C}_{b}|}y^{i}_{c_{j}}\log\mathbf{p}^{i}_{\phi}(c_{j}),

where 𝐩ϕi​(cj)∈ℝsuperscriptsubscript𝐩italic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗ℝ\mathbf{p}_{\phi}^{i}(c_{j})\in\mathbb{R} denotes the classification probability for the i𝑖i-th support sample belonging to the j𝑗j-th class cjsubscript𝑐𝑗c_{j} in 𝒞bsubscript𝒞𝑏\mathcal{C}_{b}, computed by the server-model. Here ycji=1subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗1y^{i}_{c_{j}}=1 if the i𝑖i-th support sample belongs to cjsubscript𝑐𝑗c_{j}, and ycji=0subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗0y^{i}_{c_{j}}=0, otherwise. Moreover, λM​I∈[0,1]subscript𝜆𝑀𝐼01\lambda_{MI}\in[0,1] is an adjustable hyper-parameter to control the weight of ℒM​Isubscriptℒ𝑀𝐼\mathcal{L}_{MI}.

3.3. Global-to-Local Knowledge Distillation

With the learned meta-knowledge in each client transferred from the client-model to the server-model, other clients can leverage such meta-knowledge to deal with the local data insufficiency issue. However, since each meta-task only contains N𝑁N classes, directly extracting meta-knowledge in the server-model can inevitably involve meta-knowledge from other classes, which can be harmful to the learning of local meta-knowledge from these N𝑁N classes in each client. Instead, we propose a partial knowledge distillation strategy to selectively extract useful knowledge from the server-model, i.e., global-to-local knowledge distillation.

3.3.1. Partial Knowledge Distillation

Specifically, we focus on the output classification probabilities of the server-model regarding the N𝑁N classes in support set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} while ignoring other classes. In this regard, we can extract the information that is crucial for learning local meta-knowledge from these N𝑁N classes and also reduce the irrelevant information from other classes.

Particularly, we consider the same meta-task 𝒯={𝒮,𝒬}𝒯𝒮𝒬\mathcal{T}=\{\mathcal{S},\mathcal{Q}\}. We denote the output probabilities for the i𝑖i-th query sample qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} in 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q} (with label yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i}) of the server-model and the client-model as 𝐩ϕi∈ℝ|𝒞b|subscriptsuperscript𝐩𝑖italic-ϕsuperscriptℝsubscript𝒞𝑏\mathbf{p}^{i}_{\phi}\in\mathbb{R}^{|\mathcal{C}_{b}|} and 𝐩ψi∈ℝNsubscriptsuperscript𝐩𝑖𝜓superscriptℝ𝑁\mathbf{p}^{i}_{\psi}\in\mathbb{R}^{N}, respectively. It is noteworthy that the N𝑁N classes in this meta-task, denoted as 𝒞msubscript𝒞𝑚\mathcal{C}_{m}, are sampled from the base classes 𝒞bsubscript𝒞𝑏\mathcal{C}_{b} (i.e., |𝒞m|=Nsubscript𝒞𝑚𝑁|\mathcal{C}_{m}|=N and 𝒞m⊂𝒞bsubscript𝒞𝑚subscript𝒞𝑏\mathcal{C}_{m}\subset\mathcal{C}_{b}). Therefore, the output of server-model (i.e., 𝐩ϕisubscriptsuperscript𝐩𝑖italic-ϕ\mathbf{p}^{i}_{\phi}) will include the probabilities of classes in 𝒞msubscript𝒞𝑚\mathcal{C}_{m}. In particular, we enforce the probabilities of in 𝒞msubscript𝒞𝑚\mathcal{C}_{m} from the client-model to be consistent with the probabilities of the same classes from the server-model. As a result, the learning of local meta-knowledge can leverage the information of data in the same N𝑁N classes from other clients, which is encoded in the server-model. In this regard, we can handle the local data insufficiency issue by involving information from other clients while reducing the irrelevant information from other classes not in 𝒞msubscript𝒞𝑚\mathcal{C}_{m}. In particular, by utilizing the output of the server-model as the soft target for the client-model, we can achieve an objective as follows:

(16) ℒK​D=−1Q​∑i=1Q∑j=1N𝐪ϕi​(cj)​log⁡𝐪ψi​(cj),subscriptℒ𝐾𝐷1𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑖italic-ϕsubscript𝑐𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑖𝜓subscript𝑐𝑗\mathcal{L}_{KD}=-\frac{1}{Q}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{Q}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}\mathbf{q}^{i}_{\phi}(c_{j})\log\mathbf{q}^{i}_{\psi}(c_{j}),

where cjsubscript𝑐𝑗c_{j} is the j𝑗j-th class in 𝒞msubscript𝒞𝑚\mathcal{C}_{m} (i.e., the N𝑁N classes in meta-task 𝒯𝒯\mathcal{T}). 𝐪ϕi​(cj)subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑖italic-ϕsubscript𝑐𝑗\mathbf{q}^{i}_{\phi}(c_{j}) and 𝐪ψi​(cj)subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑖𝜓subscript𝑐𝑗\mathbf{q}^{i}_{\psi}(c_{j}) are the knowledge distillation values for cjsubscript𝑐𝑗c_{j} from server-model and client-model, respectively. Specifically, the values of 𝐪ϕi​(cj)subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑖italic-ϕsubscript𝑐𝑗\mathbf{q}^{i}_{\phi}(c_{j}) and 𝐪ψi​(cj)subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑖𝜓subscript𝑐𝑗\mathbf{q}^{i}_{\psi}(c_{j}) are obtained via the softmax normalization:

(17) 𝐪ϕi​(cj)=exp⁡(𝐳ϕi​(cj)/Ti)∑k=1Nexp⁡(𝐳ϕi​(ck)/Ti),subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑖italic-ϕsubscript𝑐𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐳italic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗subscript𝑇𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐳italic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝑇𝑖\mathbf{q}^{i}_{\phi}(c_{j})=\frac{\exp(\mathbf{z}_{\phi}^{i}(c_{j})/T_{i})}{\sum_{k=1}^{N}\exp(\mathbf{z}_{\phi}^{i}(c_{k})/T_{i})},
(18) 𝐪ψi​(cj)=exp⁡(𝐳ψi​(cj)/Ti)∑k=1Nexp⁡(𝐳ψi​(ck)/Ti),subscriptsuperscript𝐪𝑖𝜓subscript𝑐𝑗superscriptsubscript𝐳𝜓𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗subscript𝑇𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐳𝜓𝑖subscript𝑐𝑘subscript𝑇𝑖\mathbf{q}^{i}_{\psi}(c_{j})=\frac{\exp(\mathbf{z}_{\psi}^{i}(c_{j})/T_{i})}{\sum_{k=1}^{N}\exp(\mathbf{z}_{\psi}^{i}(c_{k})/T_{i})},

where 𝐳ϕi​(cj)superscriptsubscript𝐳italic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗\mathbf{z}_{\phi}^{i}(c_{j}) are 𝐳ψi​(cj)superscriptsubscript𝐳𝜓𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗\mathbf{z}_{\psi}^{i}(c_{j})) are the logits (i.e., output before softmax normalization) of class cjsubscript𝑐𝑗c_{j} from server-model and client-model, respectively. Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} is the temperature parameter for the i𝑖i-th query sample. In this way, we can ensure that ∑j=1N𝐪ϕi​(cj)=∑j=1N𝐪ψi​(cj)=1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐪italic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝐪𝜓𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗1\sum_{j=1}^{N}\mathbf{q}_{\phi}^{i}(c_{j})=\sum_{j=1}^{N}\mathbf{q}_{\psi}^{i}(c_{j})=1.

3.3.2. Adaptive Temperature Parameter

Generally, a larger value of Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} denotes that the client-model focuses more on extracting information from the other classes in 𝒞msubscript𝒞𝑚\mathcal{C}_{m} (Hinton et al., 2015) (i.e., {c|c∈𝒞m,c≠yi}conditional-set𝑐formulae-sequence𝑐subscript𝒞𝑚𝑐subscript𝑦𝑖\{c|c\in\mathcal{C}_{m},c\neq y_{i}\}), denoted as negative classes. Since the classification results can be erroneous in the server-model, we should adaptively adjust the value of Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} for each meta-task to reduce the adverse impact of extracting misleading information from the server-model. However, although negative classes can inherit useful information for classification, such information is generally noisier when the output probabilities of these negative classes are smaller. Therefore, to estimate the importance degree of each negative class, we consider the maximum output logit for negative classes to reduce potential noise. Particularly, if the probability of a negative class from the server-model is significantly larger than other classes, we can conjecture that this class is similar to yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} and thus potentially contains the crucial information to distinguish them. Specifically, the temperature parameter Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} for the i𝑖i-th query sample qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i} is computed as follows:

(19) Ti=σ​(maxc∈𝒞m,c≠yi⁡exp⁡(𝐳ϕi​(c))exp⁡(𝐳ϕi​(yi))),subscript𝑇𝑖𝜎subscriptformulae-sequence𝑐subscript𝒞𝑚𝑐subscript𝑦𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐳italic-ϕ𝑖𝑐superscriptsubscript𝐳italic-ϕ𝑖subscript𝑦𝑖T_{i}=\sigma\left(\frac{\max_{c\in\mathcal{C}_{m},c\neq y_{i}}\exp(\mathbf{z}_{\phi}^{i}(c))}{\exp(\mathbf{z}_{\phi}^{i}(y_{i}))}\right),

where σ​(⋅)𝜎⋅\sigma(\cdot) denotes the Sigmoid function, and yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is the label of qisubscript𝑞𝑖q_{i}. In this way, the temperature parameter Tisubscript𝑇𝑖T_{i} will increase when the ratio between the largest probability in negative classes and the probability for yisubscript𝑦𝑖y_{i} is larger. As a result, the client-model will focus more on the negative class information. Then by further incorporating the cross-entropy loss on the query set 𝒬𝒬\mathcal{Q}, we can obtain the final loss for the client-model:

(20) ℒψ=(1−λK​D)​ℒC​E​(𝒬)+λK​D​ℒK​D,subscriptℒ𝜓1subscript𝜆𝐾𝐷subscriptℒ𝐶𝐸𝒬subscript𝜆𝐾𝐷subscriptℒ𝐾𝐷\mathcal{L}_{\psi}=(1-\lambda_{KD})\mathcal{L}_{CE}(\mathcal{Q})+\lambda_{KD}\mathcal{L}_{KD},

where ℒC​E​(𝒬)subscriptℒ𝐶𝐸𝒬\mathcal{L}_{CE}(\mathcal{Q}) is defined as follows:

(21) ℒC​E​(𝒬)=−1Q​∑i=1Q∑j=1Nycji​log⁡𝐩ψi​(cj),subscriptℒ𝐶𝐸𝒬1𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑄superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝑁subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝐩𝑖𝜓subscript𝑐𝑗\mathcal{L}_{CE}(\mathcal{Q})=-\frac{1}{Q}\sum\limits_{i=1}^{Q}\sum\limits_{j=1}^{N}y^{i}_{c_{j}}\log\mathbf{p}^{i}_{\psi}(c_{j}),

where 𝐩ψi​(cj)subscriptsuperscript𝐩𝑖𝜓subscript𝑐𝑗\mathbf{p}^{i}_{\psi}(c_{j}) is the probability of the i𝑖i-th query sample belonging to class cjsubscript𝑐𝑗c_{j} computed by the client-model. ycji=1subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗1y^{i}_{c_{j}}=1 if the i𝑖i-th query sample belongs to cjsubscript𝑐𝑗c_{j}, and ycji=0subscriptsuperscript𝑦𝑖subscript𝑐𝑗0y^{i}_{c_{j}}=0, otherwise. Moreover, λK​D∈[0,1]subscript𝜆𝐾𝐷01\lambda_{KD}\in[0,1] is an adjustable hyper-parameter to control the weight of ℒK​Dsubscriptℒ𝐾𝐷\mathcal{L}_{KD}. In this manner, the client-model can selectively learn useful knowledge from both the local and global perspectives, i.e., global-to-local knowledge distillation.

3.4. Overall Learning Process

With the proposed losses ℒϕsubscriptℒitalic-ϕ\mathcal{L}_{\phi} and ℒψsubscriptℒ𝜓\mathcal{L}_{\psi}, on each round, we can conduct meta-training on each client ℂ(i)superscriptℂ𝑖\mathbb{C}^{(i)} by sampling τ𝜏\tau meta-training tasks from the local base dataset 𝒟b(i)subscriptsuperscript𝒟𝑖𝑏\mathcal{D}^{(i)}_{b}. The detailed process is described in Algorithm 1. After T𝑇T rounds of meta-training on all the clients, we have obtained a model that accommodates comprehensive meta-knowledge for federated few-shot learning. For the meta-test phase, since we have aggregated learned local meta-knowledge from each client to the server-model, we can leverage the server-model to generate data representations for classification. Specifically, during evaluation, for each meta-test task 𝒯={𝒮,𝒬}𝒯𝒮𝒬\mathcal{T}=\{\mathcal{S},\mathcal{Q}\} sampled from local novel datasets {𝒟n(i)}i=1Isuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑛𝑖𝑖1𝐼\{\mathcal{D}_{n}^{(i)}\}_{i=1}^{I} in all clients, we follow the same process as meta-training including fine-tuning, except that the meta-update process is omitted. The output of the client-model will be used for classification.

4. Experiments

In this part, we conduct extensive experiments to evaluate our framework F2L on four few-shot classification datasets covering both news articles and images under the federated scenario.

4.1. Datasets

In this section, we introduce four prevalent real-world datasets used in our experiments, covering both news articles and images: 20 Newsgroup (Lang, 1995), Huffpost (Misra, 2018; Misra and Grover, 2021), FC100 (Oreshkin et al., 2018), and miniImageNet (Vinyals et al., 2016). In particular, 20 Newsgroup and Huffpost are online news article datasets, while FC100 and miniImageNet are image datasets. The details are as follows:

  • •

    20 Newsgroup (Lang, 1995) is a text dataset that consists of informal discourse from news discussion forums. There are 20 classes for documents in this dataset, where each class belongs to one of six top-level categories. The classes are split as 8/5/7 for training/validation/test, respectively.

  • •

    Huffpost (Misra, 2018; Misra and Grover, 2021) is a text dataset containing news headlines published on HuffPost222https://www.huffpost.com/ between 2012 and 2018. Generally, the headlines are significantly shorter and less grammatical than the 20 Newsgroup dataset. Moreover, each headline belongs to one of 41 classes, which are then split as 20/5/16 for training/validation/test, respectively.

  • •

    FC100 (Oreshkin et al., 2018) is an image classification dataset based on CIFAR-100 (Krizhevsky et al., 2009). Specifically, this dataset contains 100 image classes, where each class maintains 600 images with a low 32×32323232\times 32 resolution. The classes are split as 60/20/20 for training/validation/test, respectively.

  • •

    miniImageNet (Vinyals et al., 2016) is an image dataset extracted from the full ImageNet dataset (Deng et al., 2009). This dataset consists of 100 image classes, and each class maintains 600 images with a resolution of 84×84848484\times 84. The classes are split as 64/16/20 for training/validation/test, respectively.

4.2. Experimental Settings

To validate the performance of our framework F2L, we conduct experiments with the following baselines for a fair comparison:

  • •

    Local. This baseline is non-distributed, which means we train an individual model for each client on the local data. The meta-test process is conducted on all meta-test tasks, and the averaged results of all models are reported.

  • •

    FL-MAML. This baseline leverages the MAML (Finn et al., 2017) strategy to perform meta-learning on each client. The updated model parameters will be sent back to the server for aggregation.

  • •

    FL-Proto. This baseline uses ProtoNet (Snell et al., 2017) as the model in each client. The classification is based on the Euclidean distances between query samples and support samples.

  • •

    FedFSL (Fan and Huang, 2021). This method combines MAML and an adversarial learning strategy (Goodfellow et al., 2014; Saito et al., 2018) to construct a consistent feature space. The aggregation is based on FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017).

During meta-training, we perform updates for the client-model and the server-model according to Algorithm 1. Finally, the server-model that achieves the best result on validation will be used for meta-test. Then during meta-test, we evaluate the server-model on a series of 100 randomly sampled meta-test tasks from local novel datasets {𝒟n(i)}i=1Isuperscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝒟𝑛𝑖𝑖1𝐼\{\mathcal{D}_{n}^{(i)}\}_{i=1}^{I} in all clients. For consistency, the class split of 𝒞bsubscript𝒞𝑏\mathcal{C}_{b} and 𝒞nsubscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{C}_{n} is identical for all baseline methods. The classification accuracy over these meta-test tasks will be averaged as the final results. The specific parameter settings are provided in Appendix C.3. For the specific choices for the encoder and classifier in server-model and client-model (i.e., qϕsubscript𝑞italic-ϕq_{\phi}, fϕsubscript𝑓italic-ϕf_{\phi}, qψsubscript𝑞𝜓q_{\psi}, and fψsubscript𝑓𝜓f_{\psi}) and model parameters, we provide further details in Appendix C.1. Note that for a fair comparison, we utilize the same encoder for all methods.

4.3. Overall Evaluation Results

We present the overall performance comparison of our framework and baselines on federated few-shot learning in Table 1. Specifically, we conduct experiments under two few-shot settings: 5-way 1-shot and 5-way 5-shot. Moreover, to demonstrate the robustness of our framework under different data distributions, we partition the data in both IID and non-IID settings. For the IID partition, the samples of each class are uniformly distributed to all clients. For non-IID partition, we follow the prevailing strategy (Hsu et al., 2019; Yu et al., 2020) and distribute samples to all clients based on the Dirichlet distribution with its concentration parameter set as 1.0. The evaluation metric is the average classification accuracy over ten repetitions. From the overall results, we can obtain the following observations:

  • •

    Our framework F2L outperforms all other baselines on various news article and image datasets under different few-shot settings (1-shot and 5-shot) and data distributions (IID and non-IID). The results validate the effectiveness of our framework on federated few-shot learning.

  • •

    Conventional few-shot methods such as Prototypical Network (Snell et al., 2017) and MAML (Finn et al., 2017) exhibit similar performance compared with the Local baseline. The result demonstrates that directly applying few-shot methods to federated learning brings less competitive improvements over local training. This is because such methods are not proposed for federated learning and thus lead to unsatisfactory training performance under the federated setting.

  • •

    The performance of all methods degrades at different extents when the data distribution is changed from IID to non-IID. The main reason is that the variety of classes in each client results in a more complex class distribution and brings difficulties to the classification task. Nevertheless, by effectively transferring the meta-knowledge among clients, our framework is capable of alleviating such a problem under the non-IID scenario.

  • •

    When increasing the value of K𝐾K (i.e., more support samples in each class), all methods achieve considerable performance gains. In particular, our framework F2L obtains better results compared to other baselines, due to our decoupled meta-learning framework, which promotes the learning of meta-knowledge in the support samples.

4.4. Ablation Study

In this part, we conduct an ablation study on FC100 and Huffpost to validate the effectiveness of three crucial designs in F2L (similar results observed in other datasets). First, we remove the decoupled strategy so that the client-model will also be sent to the server for aggregation. We refer to this variant as F2L\M. Second, we remove the local-to-global knowledge transfer module so that the meta-knowledge in the client-model will be effectively transferred to the server-model. This variant is referred to as F2L\T. Third, we eliminate the global-to-local knowledge distillation loss. In this way, the client-model cannot leverage the global knowledge in the server-model for learning meta-knowledge. We refer to this variant as F2L\A. The overall ablation study results are presented in Fig. 4. From the results, we observe that F2L outperforms all variants, which verifies the effectiveness of the three designs in F2L. Specifically, removing the design of local-to-global knowledge transfer leads to significant performance degradation. This result demonstrates that such a design can effectively aggregate learned meta-knowledge among clients and thus bring performance improvements. More significantly, without our decoupled strategy, the performance deteriorates rapidly when federated few-shot learning is conducted in the non-IID scenario. This phenomenon verifies the importance of mitigating the disruption from the server in the presence of complex data distributions among clients.

4.5. Parameter Sensitivity Study

4.5.1. Effect of λM​Isubscript𝜆𝑀𝐼\lambda_{MI} and λK​Dsubscript𝜆𝐾𝐷\lambda_{KD}

In this section, we further conduct experiments to study the sensitivity of several parameters in our framework F2L. During the process of transferring and achieving meta-knowledge, we introduce two novel losses ℒM​Isubscriptℒ𝑀𝐼\mathcal{L}_{MI} and ℒK​Dsubscriptℒ𝐾𝐷\mathcal{L}_{KD}, respectively, along with the traditional cross-entropy loss. To empirically evaluate the impact brought by different values of λM​Isubscript𝜆𝑀𝐼\lambda_{MI} and λK​Dsubscript𝜆𝐾𝐷\lambda_{KD} in Eq. (14) and Eq. (20) , we adjust the values of λM​Isubscript𝜆𝑀𝐼\lambda_{MI} and λK​Dsubscript𝜆𝐾𝐷\lambda_{KD} from 00 to 111 and present the results in Fig 5. From the results, we can observe that the performance generally increases with a larger value of λM​Isubscript𝜆𝑀𝐼\lambda_{MI}, while decreasing with λM​Isubscript𝜆𝑀𝐼\lambda_{MI} approaches 1. The results indicate the importance of transferring learned local meta-knowledge, while also demonstrating that the cross-entropy loss is necessary. On the other hand, the performance first increases and then degrades when a larger value of λK​Dsubscript𝜆𝐾𝐷\lambda_{KD} is presented. That being said, although partial knowledge distillation can enable each client to benefit from the global data, a larger λK​Dsubscript𝜆𝐾𝐷\lambda_{KD} can potentially lead to more irrelevant information when learning local meta-knowledge.

4.5.2. Effect of Client Number

In this section, we study the robustness of our framework under the scenario with a varying number of clients. In particular, we keep the total training data unchanged, which means with more clients participating in the training process, each client preserves fewer training samples. As a result, the training performance will be inevitably reduced. Specifically, we partition the total training data into I=1,2,5,10,20,𝐼1251020I=1,2,5,10,20, and 505050 clients. Note that I=1𝐼1I=1 denotes the setting of completely centralized training. The results on FC100 with 1-shot and 5-shot settings are presented in Fig 6 (we have similar results for other datasets and omit them for brevity). From the results, we can observe that all methods encounter a performance drop in the presence of more clients. Nevertheless, our framework F2L can reduce the adverse impact brought by more clients through effectively leveraging the global knowledge learned from all clients. In consequence, the performance degradation is less significant for F2L.

5. Related Work

5.1. Few-shot Learning

The objective of Few-shot Learning (FSL) is to learn transferable meta-knowledge from tasks with abundant information and generalize such knowledge to novel tasks that consist of only limited labeled samples (Sun et al., 2019; Du et al., 2020; Wang et al., 2021; Tan et al., 2022a; Ding et al., 2020). Existing few-shot learning works can be divided into two categories: metric-based methods and optimization-based methods. The metric-based methods target at learning generalizable metric functions to classify query samples by matching them with support samples (Liu et al., 2019; Sung et al., 2018; Wang et al., 2022b). For instance, Prototypical Networks (Snell et al., 2017) learn a prototype representation for each class and conduct predictions based on the Euclidean distances between query samples and the prototypes. Relation Networks (Sung et al., 2018) learn relation scores for classification in a non-linear manner. On the other hand, optimization-based approaches generally optimize model parameters based on the gradients calculated from few-shot samples (Mishra et al., 2018; Ravi and Larochelle, 2016; Khodak et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2022a). As an example, MAML (Finn et al., 2017) proposes to optimize model parameters based on gradients on support samples to achieve fast generalization. In addition, LSTM-based meta-learner (Ravi and Larochelle, 2016) adjusts the step size to adaptively update parameters during meta-training.

5.2. Federated Learning

Federated Learning (FL) enables multiple clients to collaboratively train a model without exchanging the local data explicitly (Yang et al., 2019; Kairouz et al., 2021; T Dinh et al., 2020; Li and Wang, 2019; Zhu et al., 2021; Fu et al., 2022). As a classic example, FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017) performs stochastic gradient descent (SGD) on each client to update model parameters and send them to the server. The server averages the received model parameters to achieve a global model for the next round. FedProx (Li et al., 2020) incorporates a proximal term into the local update of each client to reduce the distance between the global model and the local model. To deal with the non-IID problem in FL, recent works also focus on personalization in FL (Fallah et al., 2020; Arivazhagan et al., 2019; Tan et al., 2022b; Bui et al., 2019). For instance, FedMeta (Chen et al., 2018) incorporates MAML (Finn et al., 2017) into the local update process in each client for personalization. FedRep (Collins et al., 2021) learns shared representations among clients. Moreover, FedFSL (Fan and Huang, 2021) proposes to combine MAML and an adversarial learning strategy (Goodfellow et al., 2014; Saito et al., 2018) to learn a consistent feature space.

6. Conclusion

In this paper, we study the problem of federated few-shot learning, which aims at learning a federated model that can achieve satisfactory performance on new tasks with limited labeled samples. Nevertheless, it remains difficult to perform federated few-shot learning due to two challenges: global data variance and local data insufficiency. To tackle these challenges, we propose a novel federated few-shot learning framework F2L. In particular, we handle global data variance by decoupling the learning of local meta-knowledge. Then we leverage the global knowledge that is learned from all clients to tackle the local data insufficiency issue. We conduct extensive experiments on four prevalent few-shot learning datasets under the federated setting, covering both news articles and images. The experimental results further validate the superiority of our framework F2L over other state-of-the-art baselines.

Appendix C Reproducibility

C.1. Model Details

In this section, we introduce the specific choices for the encoders and classifiers in both server-model and client-model (i.e., qϕsubscript𝑞italic-ϕq_{\phi}, fϕsubscript𝑓italic-ϕf_{\phi}, qψsubscript𝑞𝜓q_{\psi}, and fψsubscript𝑓𝜓f_{\psi}).

C.1.1. Server-model Encoder qϕsubscript𝑞italic-ϕq_{\phi}

For the server-model encoder, we adopt different models for news article datasets and image datasets. In particular, for news article datasets 20 Newsgroup and Huffpost, we leverage a biLSTM (Hochreiter and Schmidhuber, 1997) with 50 units as the server-model encoder. For the image datasets FC100 and miniImageNet, following (Tian et al., 2020; Ravichandran et al., 2019), we utilize a ResNet12 as the server-model encoder. Similar to (Lee et al., 2019), the Dropblock is used as a regularizer. The number of filters is set as (64, 160, 320, 640).

C.1.2. Client-model Encoder qψsubscript𝑞𝜓q_{\psi}

Considering that the client-model is required to process the entire support set in a meta-task for learning local meta-knowledge, we propose to further utilize a set-invariant function that takes a set of samples as input while capturing the correlations among these samples. In practice, we leverage the Transformer (Vaswani et al., 2017) as the client-model encoder qψsubscript𝑞𝜓q_{\psi} to process the entire support set:

(22) (𝐡ψ1,𝐡ψ2,…,𝐡ψD)=Transformer​(𝐡ϕ1,𝐡ϕ2,…,𝐡ϕD),subscriptsuperscript𝐡1𝜓subscriptsuperscript𝐡2𝜓…subscriptsuperscript𝐡𝐷𝜓Transformersubscriptsuperscript𝐡1italic-ϕsubscriptsuperscript𝐡2italic-ϕ…subscriptsuperscript𝐡𝐷italic-ϕ\left(\mathbf{h}^{1}_{\psi},\mathbf{h}^{2}_{\psi},\dotsc,\mathbf{h}^{D}_{\psi}\right)=\text{Transformer}\left(\mathbf{h}^{1}_{\phi},\mathbf{h}^{2}_{\phi},\dotsc,\mathbf{h}^{D}_{\phi}\right),

where 𝐡ϕisubscriptsuperscript𝐡𝑖italic-ϕ\mathbf{h}^{i}_{\phi} (or 𝐡ψisubscriptsuperscript𝐡𝑖𝜓\mathbf{h}^{i}_{\psi}) denotes the representation of the i𝑖i-th sample in 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} learned by the server-model encoder qϕsubscript𝑞italic-ϕq_{\phi} (or client-model encoder qψsubscript𝑞𝜓q_{\psi}). With the Transformer, the representations learned by the client-model can effectively capture the correlations among samples in the entire support set 𝒮𝒮\mathcal{S} for learning meta-knowledge.

C.1.3. Server-model Classifier fϕsubscript𝑓italic-ϕf_{\phi} and Client-model Classifier fψsubscript𝑓𝜓f_{\psi}

The classifiers fϕsubscript𝑓italic-ϕf_{\phi} and fψsubscript𝑓𝜓f_{\psi} are both implemented as a fully-connected layer, where the output size is |𝒞b|subscript𝒞𝑏|\mathcal{C}_{b}| for fϕsubscript𝑓italic-ϕf_{\phi} and N𝑁N for fψsubscript𝑓𝜓f_{\psi}, as described in Sec. 3.1.

C.2. Baseline Settings

In this section, we provide further details in the implementation of baselines in our experiments.

  • •

    Local. For this baseline, an individual model is trained for each client over the local data. Specifically, we use the same architecture of encoders in our framework to learn sample representations.

  • •

    FL-MAML. For this baseline, we leverage the MAML (Finn et al., 2017) strategy and set the meta-learning rate as 0.001 and the fine-tuning rate as 0.01. The encoders are the same as our framework.

  • •

    FL-Proto. For this baseline, we follow the setting in ProtoNet (Snell et al., 2017) with the same encoders in our framework. The learning rate is set as 0.001.

  • •

    FedFSL (Fan and Huang, 2021). For this baseline, which combines MAML and an adversarial learning strategy (Goodfellow et al., 2014; Saito et al., 2018), we follow the settings in the public code and set the learning rate as 0.001. The adaptation step size is set as 0.01.

C.3. Parameter Settings

For our framework F2L, we set the number of clients as 10. The number of training steps τ𝜏\tau in each client is set as 10, and the number of training rounds T𝑇T is set as 200. Moreover, the meta-learning rates αψsubscript𝛼𝜓\alpha_{\psi} and αϕsubscript𝛼italic-ϕ\alpha_{\phi} are both set as 0.001 with a dropout rate of 0.1. The fine-tuning learning rate αf​tsubscript𝛼𝑓𝑡\alpha_{ft} is set as 0.01. We leverage the Adam (Kingma and Ba, 2015) optimization strategy with the weight decay rate set as 10−4superscript10410^{-4}. During the meta-test, we randomly sample 100 meta-test tasks from novel classes 𝒞nsubscript𝒞𝑛\mathcal{C}_{n} with a query set size |𝒬|𝒬|\mathcal{Q}| of 5. In order to preserve consistency for fair comparisons, we keep identical meta-test tasks for all baselines. The loss weights λM​Isubscript𝜆𝑀𝐼\lambda_{MI} and λK​Dsubscript𝜆𝐾𝐷\lambda_{KD} are both set as 0.5. The default value of I𝐼I is set as 10.
